title: 108_s1451
content:
The Act is titled the "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act." It includes amendments to the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifically in Section 302 regarding findings. The Congress finds that youth who are homeless or run away from home without parental permission are at risk of serious health and behavioral problems due to lack of resources. Many of these young people urgently need temporary shelter. The Congress recognizes that homeless youth lack resources and may endanger themselves by living on the streets, creating law enforcement issues. These young people urgently need temporary shelter and linguistically appropriate services. The Federal Government should develop a national reporting system to address this interstate problem. The Federal Government must develop a national reporting system to address the interstate issue of homeless youth needing temporary shelter and linguistically appropriate services to prevent law enforcement problems. To develop an effective system of care for runaway and homeless youth, including preventive and aftercare services, emergency shelter, residential shelter, and street outreach services. Runaway youth need opportunities for education, job skills, and employment to transition successfully to adulthood. Improved coordination between Federal programs serving this population is essential. To address the needs of runaway and homeless youth, it is crucial to provide education, job skills, and employment opportunities. Improved coordination among Federal programs serving this population is necessary for a long-term strategy. The heading for part A of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to "Basic Center". Grants for services provided under the Act are also addressed. The heading for part A of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to "Basic Center". Section 311(a)(2)(C) is amended to include testing for sexually transmitted diseases at the request of runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 104. Repeal of obsolete provision regarding certain allotments. Section 311(b) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to remove outdated provisions.

SEC. 105. Eligibility provision. Section 312(a) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to replace "juveniles" with "youth".

SEC. 106. Recognition of state law regarding capacity limitation on eligible runaway and homeless youth centers. SEC. 105. Eligibility provision amended to replace "juveniles" with "youth". SEC. 106. Recognition of state law relating to capacity limitation on eligible runaway and homeless youth centers amended to include compliance with higher maximum requirements for child and youth serving facilities. SEC. 107. MATERNITY GROUP HOMES. The amendment to the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act includes adding maternity group homes as eligible facilities and incorporating parenting skills into the services provided. A maternity group home is defined as a transitional living arrangement for pregnant or parenting youth. The amendment to the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act defines a maternity group home as a transitional living arrangement for pregnant or parenting youth, where they are required to learn parenting skills to promote long-term economic independence and ensure the well-being of their children. SEC. 108 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to allow youth under 18 in a program to stay until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the 540-day period. SEC. 109 addresses coordination assurances for Part A plans. SEC. 109 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to involve McKinney-Vento school district liaisons in providing educational services to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 110 addresses coordination agreements for Part B plans. Section 322(a) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include coordination of services with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons to ensure that runaway and homeless youth receive information about educational services. Section 322(a) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to coordinate services with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons to provide educational information to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 111. PART B PLAN DEVELOPMENT. Amends Section 322(a)(7) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to require the development of a plan for proper referral of homeless youth to various services including education, vocational training, welfare, legal services, and health care. SEC. 112. COORDINATION OF PROGRAMS. Amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to require consultation with the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for coordination of programs and services for homeless youth. SEC. 113. CLARIFICATION OF GRANT AUTHORITY. Amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to clarify grant authority for service projects. SEC. 114. TECHNICAL AMENDMENT RELATING TO DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS. Amends the Act by removing the word "temporary" from the section heading. SEC. 115. REPEAL OF OBSOLETE PROVISION RELATING TO STUDY. Repeals a section regarding a study in the Act. SEC. 116. AGE LIMIT FOR HOMELESS YOUTH. Introduces an age limit for homeless youth. SEC. 115. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended by removing an obsolete provision relating to a study. SEC. 116. An age limit for homeless youth is introduced. SEC. 117. Authorization of appropriations. Section 388(a)(1) and 388(a)(4) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act are amended to allocate $105,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and adjust funding for fiscal years 2005-2008. Section 388(a)(2)(B) is also amended for Part B allocation. Part E of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to update funding allocations for fiscal years 2004-2008. Part B allocation is also adjusted to ensure a minimum of 45 percent funding, with a potential increase to 55 percent based on grant obligations and applicant quality. SEC. 118. REPORT ON PROMISING STRATEGIES TO END YOUTH HOMELESSNESS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness, must submit a report to Congress on promising strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years of this Act's enactment. SEC. 119. STUDY OF HOUSING SERVICES AND STRATEGIES. SEC. 119. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will study housing services and strategies for youth exiting programs funded under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. The study will focus on long-term housing outcomes, available services, placement strategies, and preventing future homelessness. SEC. 120. RESTRICTION ON USE OF FUNDS. Amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to prohibit the use of funds for distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. Requires separate accounting for funds used for such programs. AMENDMENTS TO MISSING CHILDREN'S ASSISTANCE ACT: Section 402 of the Act is amended to update findings related to missing children. The Congress finds that thousands of children are abducted each year, putting them in grave danger. Missing children are at risk of harm and exploitation, with parents and law enforcement often lacking resources for search efforts. Abducted children are frequently moved to different locations, requiring cooperation for search efforts. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children serves as a national resource center and works in partnership with law enforcement agencies to locate abducted children who are often moved to different locations. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various law enforcement agencies at local, State, and Federal levels to find missing children and prevent child victimization through a national and worldwide network. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various agencies to find missing children and prevent child victimization through a national and worldwide network, linking with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Scotland Yard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, INTERPOL headquarters, and others. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various agencies worldwide, including missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Scotland Yard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, and INTERPOL headquarters in Lyon, France, to transmit images and information about missing children to law enforcement globally. SEC. 202 of the Missing Children's Assistance Act is amended to authorize appropriations for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children until 2008. This amendment was passed by the Senate on September 26, 2003. The Senate passed S. 1451 on September 26, 2003, reauthorizing programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act and the Missing Children's Assistance Act.
